revised_title: Thermal Regulation and Respiratory Exchange in Monotremes and Marsupials
tldr: This study investigates the thermal adjustment and respiratory exchange in monotremes and marsupials, comparing their homothermism development with control experiments on cold-blooded animals and higher mammals. The main conclusions are that echidnas have the lowest level of warm-blooded animals, while ornithorhyncus has a fairly constant body temperature. Marsupials show evidence of utilizing variations in heat loss to a greater extent than ornithorhyncus but less than higher mammals. The paper also discusses the evolution of warm-blooded animals and their mechanisms for varying heat production and loss.
